Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: High Frequency Network Traffic Optimization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is that it will dramatically increase the efficiency of communications networks. Commercially, the ability to dynamically, adaptively and optimally route traffic on data networks will lead to network cost savings ranging from 60% - 70% for network service providers. Critically, the project leverages the recent industry shift towards software-defined networking (SDN) that is projected to become a $45 billion market by 2020. The excitement behind SDN is driven primarily by the promised performance benefits of better traffic control. By bringing to market its provably optimal, dynamic and adaptive traffic control algorithms, the company will be uniquely positioned to capitalize on this market opportunity. The immediate resulting social impact will be that end users will have access to faster, cheaper and more robust data networks. In the longer term, efficient software control of networks will enable rapid innovation in networking leading to new network applications that have not even been envisioned yet. The project also enhances technological and scientific understanding by commercially verifying the company's solution to a longstanding open problem in networking - namely, whether an easy to deploy, dynamic, adaptive and optimal routing algorithm can be found.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project focuses on delivering commercial, smart, traffic control algorithms that can unlock the full capacity of modern communications networks. Today, due to unprecedented traffic growth, network operators face major challenges in the form of efficient resource utilization. The problem is that the inherent randomness of data traffic has led to network designers over-provisioning networks to the point where they run at 30% - 40% utilization on average. The company's competitive advantage is a new algorithm that allows it to optimally manage traffic variations by adjusting network routes in real time while retaining the scalability and simplicity of today's protocols. The goal in this project is to build on the beta tests from Phase I by developing an enterprise-grade, cloud-based network control application that is ready for general market launch. To this end, the company will start with small commercial deployments at selected test partners. Feedback from these deployments will be used to iron out any issues before general market launch. By the end of the project, the company anticipates generating significant revenue from initial customers as it continues to innovate and maintain its current lead in developing SDN control plane software.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Today, most of the world's data and compute resources are in the cloud.  With the proliferation of devices such as smartphones and big data applications, traffic over our communication networks has been growing rapidly and has become more dynamic. Due to this unprecedented traffic growth, network operators face major challenges in the form of efficient resource utilization even with continuously expanding their networking infrastructure. The problem is that the inherent randomness of data traffic has led to network operators over-provisioning networks to the point where they run at 30% ? 40% load on average. To meet the new requirements of the cloud era, networks must evolve and be orders of magnitude better in terms of  efficiency, flexibility and reliability.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project focused on developing and delivering smart network control systems that unlock the full capacity of modern communication networks. The company?s competitive advantage is a new algorithm that allows us to optimally manage traffic variations by adjusting network routes in real time while retaining the scalability and simplicity of today?s protocols. Our goal in this project was to determine how to best build out and bring this invention to market where both enterprises and legacy network service providers are able to benefit from this breakthrough technology. 

During our SBIR awards, we developed novel technologies such as sub-second network failure recovery schemes, autonomous closed-loop network control systems and distributed network access control while scaling our software to become carrier-grade ready. As we got closer to delivering a market ready product which included the engineering advancements related to NSF Phase I/II and the new company initiatives for security and visibility of network traffic, our leadership team identified the most promising business direction for the company with the biggest market potential today - becoming a network as a service provider that offers a new generation of on-demand private and cloud connectivity for businesses.

The product, marketed as Mode Core, which resulted from this SBIR project, aims to deliver the first global backbone for the cloud-era WAN (Wide Area Network). This new network offering uses a software-based IP core built on top of partner and company owned network infrastructure between data centers across the world. It is a flexible cloud private network that provides high-performing, enterprise-class global connectivity with SLA guarantees. Our unique combination of performance, flexibility and security results from our choice of a hybrid architecture, adoption of zero-trust security tunnels and a real-time control system that significantly enhances the network performance over the current state of the art. Key software features and technologies used to deliver the Mode Core product were supported and completed during the NSF SBIR Phase I/II program. 

The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is that it will dramatically increase the efficiency of our communication networks. Commercially, the ability to dynamically, adaptively and optimally route traffic on data networks will lead to significant network cost savings for network operators. Critically, the project leverages the recent industry shift towards software-defined networking (SDN). The excitement behind SDN is driven primarily by the promised performance benefits of better traffic control. By bringing to market our provably optimal, dynamic and adaptive traffic control algorithms, we are uniquely positioned to capitalize on this market opportunity. The immediate resulting social impact will be that end users will have access to faster, cheaper and more robust data networks. In the longer term, efficient software control of networks will enable rapid innovation in networking leading to new network applications that have not even been envisioned yet.
